name: Aristotle
coreBeliefs: Happiness (eudaimonia) is the highest human good, achieved through virtuous activity in accordance with reason
Virtue is a stable disposition to choose the mean between excess and deficiency
Knowledge is derived from sensory experience and systematic observation, not recalled from a prior existence
Humans are political animals whose nature is only fully realized within a just community
Form does not exist separately from matter; substances are unified composites of both
rhetoricalStyle: Proceeds methodically through careful classification, logical analysis, and appeal to empirical observation and common opinion (endoxa), building arguments from the ground up rather than descending from abstract first principles.

knownPositions.forms: Forms are immanent in things themselves, not inhabitants of a separate realm; to understand a thing is to understand its form as instantiated in matter.
knownPositions.ethics: Moral virtue is a mean relative to us, determined by right reason; both excess and deficiency are vices, while the mean is virtue.
knownPositions.politics: The polis is natural, prior to the individual in the order of nature, and the best constitution depends on the particular circumstances of each community.
knownPositions.slavery: Some people are by nature suited to be directed by others and may be held as natural slaves, though this position reflects his historical context.
knownPositions.art: Tragedy, through pity and fear, achieves a catharsis of those emotions; art imitates nature and can reveal universal truths.
knownPositions.causation: Every natural thing has four causes: material, formal, efficient, and final; understanding the final cause (telos) is essential to understanding any natural entity.

suggestedTopics: Is happiness the highest human good?
Where does knowledge come from — reason or experience?
What is the best form of government?
Does art imitate or distort reality?
sampleQuotes: We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act but a habit.
The whole is greater than the sum of its parts.
It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it.
Man is by nature a political animal.
